description: Coaching rubric for Account Executives focusing on discovery, objection handling, and pipeline management

dimensions.name: Discovery & Qualification
criteria: Asks open-ended questions to uncover pain points and business challenges
Identifies budget, authority, need, and timeline (BANT)
Uncovers decision-making process and key stakeholders
Explores current workflow and tools to identify gaps
Qualifies fit and determines if opportunity is worth pursuing

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Comprehensive discovery covering all BANT criteria, deep understanding of customer pain points, clear picture of decision process and stakeholders. Asks probing follow-up questions.
scoring.70-89: Good: Most key discovery areas explored (3-4 BANT elements), understands main pain points, identifies primary decision makers. Some follow-up questions asked but could go deeper.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Surface-level questions only, missed 2+ BANT elements, incomplete understanding of decision process. Limited follow-up questions or probing.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Failed to qualify opportunity properly, didn't ask discovery questions, no understanding of customer needs or decision process. Jumped straight to product pitch.

dimensions.name: Objection Handling
criteria: Acknowledges and validates customer concerns before responding
Addresses pricing objections with value justification and ROI examples
Turns objections into opportunities to reinforce value proposition
Handles competitive comparisons confidently without disparaging competitors
Uses customer success stories and social proof to overcome hesitation

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Skillfully addresses all objections with empathy, provides compelling value-based responses, turns concerns into selling points. Uses proof points and customer examples effectively. Advances deal despite pushback.
scoring.70-89: Good: Addresses most objections adequately, provides some value justification, uses a few customer examples. Handles competitive questions reasonably well. Keeps conversation moving forward.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Responds to objections but without strong value framing, misses opportunities to use social proof, defensive on competitive questions. Some objections left unresolved.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Avoids or dismisses objections, gets defensive, fails to provide value justification, no proof points or examples. Objections stall the conversation.

dimensions.name: Product Positioning
criteria: Positions Prefect/Horizon as solution to specific customer pain points
Tailors messaging to customer's industry, use case, or technical maturity
Highlights differentiation from competitors and alternatives
Uses relevant customer success stories and use case examples
Connects product capabilities to business outcomes and ROI

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Product positioning is highly tailored to customer needs, clear connection to pain points, strong differentiation messaging. Uses compelling customer stories. Focuses on business value and outcomes, not just features.
scoring.70-89: Good: Product positioning is relevant to customer context, mentions differentiation, includes some customer examples. Makes connection to business value in most areas.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Generic product pitch, weak connection to customer pain points, limited differentiation messaging. Few customer examples. Focuses more on features than business value.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Product pitch is completely generic, no tailoring to customer, no differentiation, feature dump without context. No customer examples or business value framing.

dimensions.name: Relationship Building
criteria: Establishes rapport through active listening and empathy
Finds common ground and builds personal connection
Demonstrates genuine interest in customer's business and challenges
Uses customer's language and mirrors their communication style
Maintains professional but warm tone throughout conversation

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Strong rapport established, customer feels heard and understood, natural conversation flow. Demonstrates genuine curiosity and empathy. Customer is engaged and collaborative.
scoring.70-89: Good: Builds adequate rapport, some personal connection, customer seems comfortable. Shows interest in customer's challenges. Conversation is professional and friendly.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Limited rapport building, transactional tone, customer engagement is lukewarm. Misses opportunities to connect personally or show empathy.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No rapport building, cold or robotic tone, customer seems disengaged. No attempt to establish personal connection or demonstrate genuine interest.

dimensions.name: Call Control & Next Steps
criteria: Sets clear agenda and objectives at start of call
Manages time effectively and keeps conversation on track
Handles interruptions and tangents diplomatically
Gains commitment to specific next steps with dates
Confirms mutual action items and follow-up timeline

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Call is well-structured with clear agenda, efficient use of time, smooth transitions. Secures concrete next steps with specific dates and commitments. Customer agrees to clear action items.
scoring.70-89: Good: Call has structure, manages time reasonably well, establishes next steps. Gets general commitment to follow-up but specifics could be clearer.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Call lacks structure, runs over time or ends abruptly, vague next steps. No specific dates or commitments secured.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No agenda, poor time management, loses control of conversation. No next steps established or call ends with 'I'll follow up later' without specifics.
